replies.body: So can we get a solid, 100% certain, that Summoners, the Institute, and all of that is no longer canon? This is nice and all, but it's only vague hints about what a lot of people want to hear. If you guys do indeed just want to start the narrative over, I completely stand by your choice to do so, but this transition so far is being handled somewhat awkwardly, and it'd be nice to know what really counts as "old lore" and "new lore".

Good question!

No, Summoners, the Fields of Justice and the Institute are not canon within the fictional world of Runeterra. In-game, players are still referred to as summoners - but summoners won't be part of the story.
As someone whose been very invested with in the lore; I feel like a part of me just died.

This is a legitimate question to Carnival J that I wanna ask, how far in have you gone with the "Summoners do not exist within Runeterra" bit that you've done? I don't need to know specifics, but is it too late to call for a poll from the community? When I got into the lore in the first place, one of the biggest attractions to League of Legends was the idea that I, as a player, was on some level canon in Valoran in some way. Maybe others feel differently, but ripping the Institute, Fields of Justice, and Summoners by way of retcon feels like a very big betrayal.

I feel that a story should be managed dynamically, within the universe. Not on a meta level, retconning things back and forth just to accommodate the whims of the lore writers. Seriously though, call for a popularity vote from the community on this one. If they say nay and you lot still want Summoners, the Institute, and the Fields of Justice to be out, write an in-universe excuse as to what happened.

Sidelining the Institute could be something you could do. Rather than being the all-powerful force of the land, the Institute becomes a force of arbitration or something. They observe, they mediate as requested, but they don't inherently need to be part of the immediate story you tell.

As a member of the community and ardent follower of lore, I feel it is the responsibility of the community to keep you, the narrative team, in check to some extent. It is our responsibility to make sure you don't destroy the thing you created.

The Freljord revamp? It was fine. You created a space within the lore to grow. Okay. Burning Trundle's old backstory to recreate him in Freljord? A bit painful but understandable. Trundle was an isolated character, by making him part of the Freljord lore you gave him the capacity to interact on a lore-level with other characters. The backstory shifts of various characters to fit them within Runeterra? That's actually a great thing. Now we don't have folks from anomalous sections of the universe.

Retconning the Institute, Fields of Justice, and Summoners? Questionable at best. For starters, the Institute was a big, core, integral part of what made League of Legends, League of Legends. A lot of characters only exist in their current state, because of the Institute. The subsequent lore-fallout would be incredibly painful for the community, and for Riot, I would imagine.

Short, key version of a long story? If you haven't gotten to the point of no return with your lore shifts, call a poll from the community. If they say they want to keep the Institute and Summoners, etc, find some way to shift them away from the focal point of your story without deleting them, please.

I feel the exact same way. Honestly though, before the whole community can start judging Riot's decisions I believe they need to be more specific about what they are actually doing. When I read this article I was confused, upset, and wanted to know more *specific* information. But if I interpreted it correctly:

* Summoners do not exist 
* the lore is gone 
* and we don't know what is coming next 

I am honestly feeling a pretty strong hate for Rito right now, because they just took away every unique aspect of League of Legends.

I agree with you 100%

Here's what really bothers me:

**"League as a game is about creating awesome gameplay, while League as a story is about creating deep, vibrant characters and factions inhabiting an expansive world. We don’t want to limit story because of gameplay, just like we wouldn’t limit gameplay because of story."**

What I get from this is that you, the narrative team, would like to think of these as two separate entities that can't interact deeply without hindering the quality of both. I find that really weird, considering you guys have two gigantic examples to prove that that is *not* the case: the Ionia vs. Noxus rematch & Dominion in its entirety, the former having influenced the lore of a handful of champions who came after it. I certainly wouldn't mind if the narrative team would like to use new lore/retcon old lore to *downplay* the involvement Summoners, The Insitute of War, Fields of Justice, etc. from now on, but **completely writing these elements out of LoL's history** is going too far. To put it another way, I'd rather be told a story about how the Institute of War was decommissioned/disbanded, rather than be told that it never existed to begin with.

I had a similar feeling when I was just starting to play this game. That I was a powerful summoner, that I was helping resolve conflict in Runeterra. Removing that as an integral part of the game is heartbreaking. I feel like the slight issues with the unexplained circumstances of gameplay (enemies as allies) weren't all that bothersome. Honestly I originally thought that the champions were simply "clones" that were used for normal matches while the real champs were used for big events (Ionia vs. Noxus Match). While I look forward to expansion of the lore, is it worth removing everything core from the past?

Exactly.  The way I read this article: we're creating a new form of storytelling (that has yet to occur...?  We haven't had anything of the depth of JoJ since that time) by removing all old storytelling from canon, which also makes the presence of a large number of characters (Jax, Ryze, and any character summoned from another world during the early days of League before the Institute was supposed to have placed sanctions on such practices such as Taric, Malphit, the angels, etc.) completely and utterly inexplicable.

In other words, I read it as: "we've heard you clamor for more, better story, so we'll fix this by wrecking and removing the story so we don't have to worry about the issue."  I have a feeling that is NOT what Riot was trying to communicate... so why is it the ONLY thing I got out of this entire shebang?
I dunno, myself I've never been a fan of the summoner concept. Like how the blog explains, the label of "champion" is a total farce if the "champion" is just a pawn/puppet.

I loved the summoner concept but it has some problems that need to be addressed but I'm sorely disappointed to see that it's being tackled in this manner. But I always thought it could have been done better or redefined.

...Then you're going to change the title of the game?

I mean, it's kinda hard for this to be called League of Legends without, y'now, a League.
There is no League. It's just a bunch of random Legends now.

And considering that most champions can't really be classified as Legends, I propose that this game must now be named A Bunch of Guys, Girls, And Weird Stuff Beating Eachother Up.

...Yeah, aBoGGaWSBEU doesn't flow as well as LoL...

Guess Factions is gonna have some issues then...

So are you gonna have another, Dawngate-esque reason that a group of five people constantly fight each other and die repeatedly? Or are you just gonna go 'gameplay and story segregation! this is all a metaphor for a vast conflict of armies and trade!' or something?

To an extent the gameplay and story will be separate. They're not *totally* separate, (for instance, Darius will always feel like Darius no matter where you see him, and the maps will always be evocative of actual places within the world) but there won't be an in-story justification for five unrelated champions tearing each other apart in the game over and over.

Huh. That's really off putting. Like, I get that it can be hard to justify that sort of gameplay, but if they're basically unrelated, then why should I care about what happens in the lore if it's not gonna effect my game? I mean, I enjoy reading stories, so I'll still be following it, but why would average Joe playerbase care if Lissandra has defeated Sejuani if you play the game without that ever becoming relevant?

I mean, even WoW has some of it's novel characters do things in the game, and they have things that happen in the novels be important to the story.

This is true, but at the same time gameplay really doesn't justify story. Why would Lucian and Thresh ever be on the same team? Why would Garen and Lux fight each other? Short answer is: they wouldn't. Summoners and the Institute explained it, but at the cost of creating a host of problems in other places. Should the story overall suffer in order to explain gameplay? Gameplay influences story in much the same way that story influences gameplay, but neither should be completely tied to one another. The two are closer linked in WoW because WoW is an RPG that is inherently part of a story. LoL is an arena style fighting match where story never really comes into play (in terms of gameplay).

Will the "Average Joe" care about Lissandra and Sejuani fighting without an excuse plot? Maybe. But, at the same time, I don't think that gives 100% validation for an excuse plot.
Why would Lucian and Thresh ever be on the same team? Because they both swore an oath to the League, which means that outside of the most major disputes they must fight for anyone who summons them.

I guess so, but then why bother having the story be related to League at all, and not just 'the world of Runeterra'? 

I just don't really see the problems with the Summoners and the Institute. The only complaint I've seen is 'it's weird that Cho'Gath could be bound by faceless characters!' and I don't see the problem in that. Most of the champs are fighting in order to curry favor with the institute, except for ones that are just in it for the money, the slaughter, or are forced to do so for some reason or another. I just don't see why it needed to be changed. It's only an excuse plot because Riot never did anything with it.

So why are half these Champions even fighting, let alone against their friends and allies?  How are they getting to the Rift, the Scar, the Abyss?  How are they constantly dying but coming back about a minute later?  How are some not dominating others just out of sheer power?

You are eliminating a number of characters you can explore, as well, like Vessaria Kolminye.  And what about someone like Lee Sin, who became a monk after failing a summoning and killing a kid and destroying his village?

This is ambitious, and possibly too much so.  I'm not impressed with what changes have already been made, and this disappoints me even further.  But I'm one dissenting voice among many, and I'll be easily drowned out.

Literally everything you said is the same thing I've been thinking. I really detest Riot for making this change and found I enjoyed the Lore made in the past instead of recently. I know I can't see the future, but what I understand of it, I don't enjoy.

A question towards the Summoner, FoJ, and Institute not being canon... What about champions such as {{champion:63}} {{champion:56}} {{champion:9}} and {{champion:35}} , who have been locked up by summoners in the Institute to prevent them from creating mass chaos and destruction? And {{champion:24}} would have had no other reason to just use a lamp post as a weapon without the Institute. It just seems like a lot of the champions that are 'inherently evil' would be much harder to tell stories for without changing their character entirely. Also, like this the game itself and the lore are completely separated, which is a very strange move toward storytelling for a game.

A character can remain evil without being locked up by the summoners. Now it's just a matter of that evil being present in the world, roaming about freely and causing chaos that's defended against by others. If anything it leads to more character interactions, more possibilities, and more stories. As for the iconic Jax lamp post, there could be an entirely new reason as to why he uses it, or maybe it's just out of arrogance to show how strong he is. Jax is Jax still, even if his lore is different.

Yeaa...{{champion:9}} was created by a Summoner going mad in my opinion. And {{champion:56}} was attacking summoners in their sleep, and he sprouted out on the Twisted Treeline in front of the Nexus from a summoner If I recall correctly. Jax would have almost NO purpose for showing up unless one of the factions hired him and then he just wouldn't really feel like Jax

Also, to be clear, we don't want people to think we're doing away with everything that's ever been posted in the Journals, Judgments, or other places. That stuff will always exist to be enjoyed, as it should -- a lot of players love it. It's about modifying things that get in the way of our telling bigger, better stories. It's kind of like with comic books: Wolverine in a '60s X-Men comic looks a lot different from Hugh Jackman in the DoFP movie, but he's still recognizably the same character. Superman's origin story has been retold numerous times and ways in many different media; some of the interpretations I've loved, others I haven't so much, but it's always fascinating to see those new perspectives on familiar tales. New doesn't invalidate old, it just broadens the world of stories told about Runeterra.

A quick question if I may. Not sure how this will come across, but I'd just like to know if with this in mind, does that mean that lore that included the institute before, such as the whole JoJ, happened but without the League existing? Or is there a different way of thinking about it? I get this is a bit weird to ask, but I'm kinda curious. Also thanks for taking the time to talk about this in the first place.

Happy to do it. I guess the best way to sum up our approach going forward is that we want to, in the words of my colleague Glorft, "do no harm, and respect core themes." The key word in terms of what both you guys are saying is "core." What falls into that category is somewhat subjective; you might think killing Superman and then reviving him as four different people for a while still stayed faithful to the core themes of the character, since each of the four was meant to personify an aspect of his character. I might disagree. There's no right or wrong. Some players may feel that getting rid of the Institute of War and Fields of Justice cuts too close to the bone as far as core themes of LoL; we've thought about it long and hard, though, and decided that, in our opinion as stewards of the game and its fictional world, the pluses of doing so outweigh the minuses (by quite a bit, frankly). We hope you ultimately agree, but we know not every single LoL player will agree with every choice we make. Doesn't mean we're not listening, though, and it certainly doesn't mean we make any such choices casually. You'd be surprised how long and hard all of this has been debated within Riot before we arrived at a place we all felt good about.

The League was basically the ONLY major part of the lore. Everything revolved around the League. All the other factions played nice to the league or suffered sanctions, the league was what ran the gameplay, the league was full of the player characters (summoners) etc. Like, you can say 'the champions were what really mattered' but champions aren't themes or plots, they're characters. Give me a couple of days and I could give you a piece of fiction in which all of the champions go to a high school together. Characters go wherever the author wants them to go. 

What ARE those pluses that removing the league would give you to work with? I haven't heard anything about those.

Hey @hellioning -- Sorry, I'm having some tech issues, so I have to reply to your "pluses" question up here. We tried to give a sense of what some of the benefits will be in the dev blog -- e.g. champions as puppets takes away their agency as characters, having all wars be fought by proxy between gladiators removes one of the main sources of conflict available to a fantasy universe, etc.  More of them will emerge over time.  Regarding the League itself, it certainly is the device in the game that justifies why these folks are fighting each other over and over on a square map with straight paths, but in anything like a real-world setting it doesn't make a lot of sense.  Garen probably wouldn't beat up on his sister; Ashe doesn't really die eight million times a day.  It's a game.  We want to start telling more stories outside the game context, and some of those game elements just don't work outside that context.  It's really not any more complicated than that.  (None of that invalidates the emotional importance those game elements have for you, me, or anyone else, though.  They'll all still be there in the game whenever you play it.)

First off, I maintain my stance regarding the 'champs as puppets' things. I don't think it affects them negatively if they're controlled by summoners, because they chose to be in that position, barring the occasional crazy. I suppose it might make more sense to just remove summoners from the equation, but you're doing more than that.

Secondly, just because war is a main source of conflict doesn't mean you have to use it in your story. 'Battle by gladiator' is far more unique than 'and then the two armies fought each other.' Neither is necessarily better than the other, but removing the trial by gladiator thing is removing one of the things that made league lore more unique. I have loads of choices if I want to watch armies fight.

I don't care about 'real-world' settings. I'm not here for realistic depictions of medieval combat, I'm here for the guy with swordboots and the giant armadillo that doesn't talk but can taunt you anyway. I don't mind if something is silly or illogical in the real world so long as it's internally consistent.

It is entirely possible to create stories outside of the game context and have that context still exist. Have Demacia debate other whether they would prefer to deal with a Noxian incursion through the official league channels or through their own army, possibly risking league sanctions. Have a hearing other whether the allegations of possible Zaunite tampering in the summoning process caused the bond between Ez and his summoner to be too weak to handle in the latest show match. 

This is reminding me of why you guys decided to retcon Trundle's lore so heavily. 'We couldn't think of anything to do with this, so let's just change everything!' That's not endearing, Tommy Gnox.

Please, please do not actually go through with a retcon of "League of Legends and Summoners no longer exist".

Unnecessary and over-done retcons are the *MAIN* reasons why I myself no longer read any Marvel/DC comics. You can't go more than a few months without a character's backstory or anything being changed because it needs to be "up-to date".

Doing this to the lore of the game will likely annoy players who have the same grievances as me.

....


Or you can keep going through with it and just have the reasoning for the game itself be a rip-off of DotA2, because seriously, that's honestly how it's starting to look now. 


Honestly, the League of Legends and Summoners were the *ONLY* thing separating League's lore from being another bland clone of DotA2, Heroes of Newerth, Smite or any other MOBA out there. Without them, League is now another generic MOBA without a real story as to *WHY* the characters are fighting.
amen!

{{champion:99}} "Tactical decision, summoner."

{{champion:86}} "(Who is she talking to...?)"
{{champion:86}} "To the Fields of... where am I?
{{champion:21}} "Think you can handle me, uh, self?"
{{champion:82}} You only need to... wait what
{{champion:76}} "You cannot cage...summoner?!"
{{champion:7}} Patience......... summoner?

Yeah, no one can hear her now.  As if I wasn't depressed enough after reading this article.  I mean, I can't even begin to comprehend the number of character bios, conventions, and voice-over lines that would need to be redone to make this retcon work, and I can think of few of these that I would like changed.

Okay, first and foremost **I want that art in their full, glorious sizes**.

As to the questions posed at the end of the blog:


>  What stories do you want us to tell? 


The easy answer is "all of them", but there are a few in particular:

* The history of the Solari and Lunari faiths, from their inception to the violent destruction of the Lunari
* The new story and reasoning behind the Institute of War
* The Bioforge vs Steel Legion alternate timeline


>What parts of Runeterra would you like to see?


* Ionia - with a number of champions from there including a couple favorites (Wukong and Karma), I'm curious to know how what life is like there, especially from the eyes of a non-Champion
* Mount Targon - with the dark history of the Solari, and the mountain range being the last barrier between Shurima and greener pastures, there are bound to be countless untold secrets and dangers among the mountain range
* Piltover - The stories of Vi trying to figure out her past, the constant struggle to keep Jinx in check, these are both great, but I'm also curious about the general life there, since from what I've seen it's like a League-inspired, technomagical version of Robots

I know a lot of people didn't read this, but I really am thankful for this blog.  Lore and cinematics and the like are one of my favorite things about LoL and I'm really happy you guys are trying to get back to that.  Honestly, I think that no matter what form it's in- newspapers like JoJ, cinematic, new lore, or even just serial short stories focusing on different champs,  new content would be well received.  Thanks Riot, for listening to the response of us players :)

Listen, we're thankful that you care. It's our job and our honor to listen to you guys and to do our best to create champions and stories that are worthy of your passion for LoL. As far as new content, I can't give anything specific away, but I have noted in my life that quiet often means cool change is coming. :-)

Yes, change is all fine and good, but if it's your 'job and ... honor  to listen', then maybe you SHOULD listen to the near 100 downvotes you and Carnival have collected on this page and see that the community thinks retconning the US, literally US, out of the lore makes us kind of unhappy.

"It's our job and our honor to listen to you guys and to do our best to create champions and stories that are worthy of your passion for LoL."
Then do not Do this!

I feel like we're all thinking it in some way or form: what does this really mean for the story? In my 2+ years of playing the game the supposed "story" was the one thing I never felt developed really at all. I've had hopes that as new champs came out new things would be revealed, and while it has happened in some small ways (Yasuo/Riven is a recent example) there's never seemed to be a real PUSH to move the story forward. As it's possible League is in it's prime right NOW, I'd really like to see some sort of exponential growth for the story in the near future. Fingers crossed this article is the start of something bigger.

Thanks for that thoughtful post. We totally understand how frustrating it may have felt for a while for those LoL players who love lore, which is one reason we really wanted to kind of kickstart things by giving you guys some idea of what we've been thinking and talking about. We've actually been building up to this moment for a while, but League is a big place and it's taken a lot of people a lot of time thinking all the possibilities through to arrive at decisions that felt right for LoL and worthy of our players. This is the beginning of something, most definitely. Please do keep talking to us and letting us know what you think and what you'd like to see!

> Please do keep talking to us and letting us know what you think and what you'd like to see!

All due respect, but some of us have been doing this for the past 18 months and we've received *nothing* from the narrative team in response.  Will this change or will we have to wait another year and a half for the Zaun/Piltover saga before we hear from the team again?

I hear you. The short answer is: we've been listening. We haven't been saying much. That's mostly been because we only want to say things that we know are true and going to happen; nobody is going to be happy if we tease something awesome that, for whatever reason, ends up not being the best way to go. That said, we want to do a better job moving forward of engaging in two-way conversation with you guys. That's the biggest reason for the dev blog you just read. That's what it's meant to kick off.
